stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the session experimenting in Blender to find a workable visual style for the new "Ice Castle" level while occasionally discussing his side-project: rewriting the N64’s libultra in pure assembly. The stream is dominated by rapid-fire texture tests, shader-combiner tinkering, and feedback loops with artist Biobak and reference images from Zeina.

development_findings.summary: The team is still in pre-production for the Ice Castle; not a single room is finalized because they want the overall art style nailed down first.
development_findings.quote: We haven't even finished one room yet, we're working on making the art stuff where it looks good before we even try to make the level.

development_findings.summary: Fog was disabled so vertex alpha could be used for high-contrast ice shaders, a trade-off Kaze considers essential for visual flexibility.
development_findings.quote: We actually removed the fog entirely so we can use the vertex alpha; if you have fog you can't use vertex alpha.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is testing multi-texturing tricks (CI4 64×64 textures, two-cycle combiners, environment maps, NF maps) to simulate bright snow over deep-blue ice without transparency.
development_findings.quote: In order to even do reflections in this moment you need to create textures from current paint then… well, of course anything is possible, but it's not very reasonable.

development_findings.summary: Main visual ideas explored: thick ice spikes on walls/ceilings, hexagonal tiles, brick-like ice blocks, and snow overlays inspired by Frozen, Adventure Time, and Mario Galaxy references.
Hardware constraints remain front-of-mind—overdraw, geometry order, and lack of true transparency—all while targeting 60 FPS on real N64 hardware.
development_findings.quote: There is both overdraw and geometry here… but it doesn't matter, because this is inside basically.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is concurrently writing a new low-level ‘operating system’ for N64 to replace libultra, entirely in assembly, to escape compiler overhead and Nintendo’s limitations.
development_findings.quote: Basically, the operating system Nintendo wrote for Mario 64 sucked… so I'm just gonna write a better one.

development_findings.summary: Quest 13 will be one of 15 total main levels, mirroring Mario 64’s original count.

context_findings.summary: Kaze works full-time as a programmer at Gears for Breakfast; Twitch streaming earns him only about $50 a month.
context_findings.quote: Disclaimer that all opinions that I share online are not the opinions of the studio I work for.

context_findings.summary: He lives in Canada and views pure assembly as ‘freedom from compiler oppression’.
context_findings.quote: We have been freed from the oppression that compilers have caused us.

context_findings.summary: Personal philosophy: art should provoke strong emotion—even if it risks backlash; he jokes a diss-track would get him ‘cancelled’.
context_findings.quote: Art is about making you feel emotion, and if I made a track like that, I would want to make you feel pure hatred.

context_findings.summary: Playful home dynamic: Zeina demands a daily ‘happy birthday’ and shaved his head when he forgot, illustrating their humorous relationship.
context_findings.quote: She got so upset… she said, dude, you are worthless, you do not deserve hair on your head—and then she just shaved me again.

biobak.summary: Acts as visual gatekeeper; repeatedly flags styles as ‘unworkable’ or too hard to maintain, influencing Kaze to discard or rethink ideas.
biobak.quote: If Biobak says this is unworkable… then we can't just use it.

biobak.summary: Expressed concerns about geometry density and spike implementation; promised to propose an alternative art direction after the stream.

zeina.summary: Provided multiple reference images (e.g., Frozen-style castles) that steered the discussion toward high-contrast deep-blue/white palettes.
Engages in lighthearted banter with Kaze, illustrating an intertwined personal/professional role during development.

key_stories.title: Ice Castle Art Style Struggle
key_stories.summary: Kaze and chat spend the entire session experimenting with textures, shaders, and geometry tricks to make an ice castle that feels mysterious yet performant on N64 hardware.
key_stories.challenge: Initial geometry and textures made the castle look like a bland ‘ice cave’ or bathroom tiles, failing to capture the intended atmosphere.
key_stories.process: He tries environment maps, removes fog, tests CI4 textures, scatters ice spikes with Geometry Nodes, and consults Biobak and Zeina for feedback and references.
key_stories.outcome: No final solution yet; Kaze pauses level work and waits for Biobak’s alternative idea, but they agree on a deep-blue/bright-white palette and the necessity of vertex-alpha shading.
key_stories.key_quote: Right now, we are exploring the space of possibilities and trying to get something that we can work with in the future that looks good.

key_stories.title: Replacing Libultra
key_stories.summary: Frustrated with Nintendo’s original libraries, Kaze begins writing a new, leaner operating system for the N64 in straight assembly language.
key_stories.challenge: Libultra (and even Mario 64’s custom OS) are inefficient and restrictive, limiting what he can do with Return to Yoshi’s Island.
key_stories.process: Off-stream he experiments with pure assembly, declaring freedom from compilers, and announces plans to shift focus to it after ending the session.
key_stories.outcome: Project is in early stages; Kaze intends to continue development immediately after the stream, aiming for better performance and flexibility.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm just gonna write a better one.

open_questions.context: Kaze ended the stream saying Biobak ‘had a good idea’ they would try next.
